column2: i am happy to join with you today in what will go down in history as the greatest demonstration for freedom in the history of our nation sep five score years ago, a great american, in whose symbolic shadow we stand today, signed the emancipation proclamation sep this momentous decree came as a great beacon light of hope to millions of negro slaves who had been seared in the flames of withering injustice sep it came as a joyous daybreak to end the long night of their captivity sep but one hundred years later, the negro still is not free sep one hundred years later, the life of the negro is still sadly crippled by the manacles of segregation and the chains of discrimination sep one hundred years later, the negro lives on a lonely island of poverty in the midst of a vast ocean of material prosperity sep one hundred years later, the negro is still languished in the corners of american society and finds himself an exile in his own land sep and so we've come here today to dramatize a shameful condition sep in a sense we've come to our nation's capital to cash a check sep when the architects of our republic wrote the magnificent words of the constitution and the declaration of independence, they were signing a promissory note to which every american was to fall heir sep this note was a promise that all men, yes, black men as well as white men, would be guaranteed the "unalienable rights" of "life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness sep " it is obvious today that america has defaulted on this promissory note, insofar as her citizens of color are concerned sep instead of honoring this sacred obligation, america has given the negro people a bad check, a check which has come back marked "insufficient funds sep "but we refuse to believe that the bank of justice is bankrupt sep we refuse to believe that there are insufficient funds in the great vaults of opportunity of this nation sep and so, we've come to cash this check, a check that will give us upon demand the riches of freedom and the security of justice sep we have also come to this hallowed spot to remind america of the fierce urgency of now sep this is no time to engage in the luxury of cooling off or to take the tranquilizing drug of gradualism sep now is the time to make real the promises of democracy sep now is the time to rise from the dark and desolate valley of segregation to the sunlit path of racial justice sep now is the time to lift our nation from the quicksands of racial injustice to the solid rock of brotherhood sep now is the time to make justice a reality for all of god's children sep it would be fatal for the nation to overlook the urgency of the moment sep this sweltering summer of the negro's legitimate discontent will not pass until there is an invigorating autumn of freedom and equality sep nineteen sixty-three is not an end, but a beginning sep and those who hope that the negro needed to blow off steam and will now be content will have a rude awakening if the nation returns to business as usual sep and there will be neither rest nor tranquility in america until the negro is granted his citizenship rights sep the whirlwinds of revolt will continue to shake the foundations of our nation until the bright day of justice emerges sep but there is something that i must say to my people, who stand on the warm threshold which leads into the palace of justice: in the process of gaining our rightful place, we must not be guilty of wrongful deeds sep let us not seek to satisfy our thirst for freedom by drinking from the cup of bitterness and hatred sep we must forever conduct our struggle on the high plane of dignity and discipline sep we must not allow our creative protest to degenerate into physical violence sep again and again, we must rise to the majestic heights of meeting physical force with soul force sep the marvelous new militancy which has engulfed the negro community must not lead us to a distrust of all white people, for many of our white brothers, as evidenced by their presence here today, have come to realize that their destiny is tied up with our destiny sep and they have come to realize that their freedom is inextricably bound to our freedom sep we cannot walk alone sep and as we walk, we must make the pledge that we shall always march ahead sep we cannot turn back sep there are those who are asking the devotees of civil rights, "when will you be satisfied sep " we can never be satisfied as long as the negro is the victim of the unspeakable horrors of police brutality sep we can never be satisfied as long as our bodies, heavy with the fatigue of travel, cannot gain lodging in the motels of the highways and the hotels of the cities sep **we cannot be satisfied as long as the negro's basic mobility is from a smaller ghetto to a larger one sep we can never be satisfied as long as our children are stripped of their self-hood and robbed of their dignity by signs stating: "for whites only sep "** we cannot be satisfied as long as a negro in mississippi cannot vote and a negro in new york believes he has nothing for which to vote sep no, no, we are not satisfied, and we will not be satisfied until "justice rolls down like waters, and righteousness like a mighty stream sep "i am not unmindful that some of you have come here out of great trials and tribulations sep some of you have come fresh from narrow jail cells sep and some of you have come from areas where your quest -- quest for freedom left you battered by the storms of persecution and staggered by the winds of police brutality sep you have been the veterans of creative suffering sep continue to work with the faith that unearned suffering is redemptive sep go back to mississippi, go back to alabama, go back to south carolina, go back to georgia, go back to louisiana, go back to the slums and ghettos of our northern cities, knowing that somehow this situation can and will be changed sep let us not wallow in the valley of despair, i say to you today, my friends sep and so even though we face the difficulties of today and tomorrow, i still have a dream sep it is a dream deeply rooted in the american dream sep i have a dream that one day this nation will rise up and live out the true meaning of its creed: "we hold these truths to be self-evident, that all men are created equal sep "i have a dream that one day on the red hills of georgia, the sons of former slaves and the sons of former slave owners will be able to sit down together at the table of brotherhood sep i have a dream that one day even the state of mississippi, a state sweltering with the heat of injustice, sweltering with the heat of oppression, will be transformed into an oasis of freedom and justice sep i have a dream that my four little children will one day live in a nation where they will not be judged by the color of their skin but by the content of their character sep i have a dream today sep i have a dream that one day, down in alabama, with its vicious racists, with its governor having his lips dripping with the words of "interposition" and "nullification" -- one day right there in alabama little black boys and black girls will be able to join hands with little white boys and white girls as sisters and brothers sep i have a dream today sep i have a dream that one day every valley shall be exalted, and every hill and mountain shall be made low, the rough places will be made plain, and the crooked places will be made straight; "and the glory of the lord shall be revealed and all flesh shall see it together sep "2this is our hope, and this is the faith that i go back to the south with sep with this faith, we will be able to hew out of the mountain of despair a stone of hope sep with this faith, we will be able to transform the jangling discords of our nation into a beautiful symphony of brotherhood sep with this faith, we will be able to work together, to pray together, to struggle together, to go to jail together, to stand up for freedom together, knowing that we will be free one day sep and this will be the day -- this will be the day when all of god's children will be able to sing with new meaning: my country 'tis of thee, sweet land of liberty, of thee i sing sep land where my fathers died, land of the pilgrim's pride, from every mountainside, let freedom ring sep and if america is to be a great nation, this must become true sep and so let freedom ring from the prodigious hilltops of new hampshire sep let freedom ring from the mighty mountains of new york sep let freedom ring from the heightening alleghenies of pennsylvania sep let freedom ring from the snow-capped rockies of colorado sep let freedom ring from the curvaceous slopes of california sep but not only that: let freedom ring from stone mountain of georgia sep let freedom ring from lookout mountain of tennessee sep let freedom ring from every hill and molehill of mississippi sep from every mountainside, let freedom ring sep and when this happens, and when we allow freedom ring, when we let it ring from every village and every hamlet, from every state and every city, we will be able to speed up that day when all of god's children, black men and white men, jews and gentiles, protestants and catholics, will be able to join hands and sing in the words of the old negro spiritual: free at last sep free at last sep thank god almighty, we are free at last

vice president johnson, mr sep speaker, mr sep chief justice, president eisenhower, vice president nixon, president truman, reverend clergy, fellow citizens: we observe today not a victory of party, but a celebration of freedom -- symbolizing an end, as well as a beginning -- signifying renewal, as well as change sep for i have sworn before you and almighty god the same solemn oath our forebears prescribed nearly a century and three-quarters ago sep the world is very different now sep for man holds in his mortal hands the power to abolish all forms of human poverty and all forms of human life sep and yet the same revolutionary beliefs for which our forebears fought are still at issue around the globe -- the belief that the rights of man come not from the generosity of the state, but from the hand of god sep we dare not forget today that we are the heirs of that first revolution sep let the word go forth from this time and place, to friend and foe alike, that the torch has been passed to a new generation of americans -- born in this century, tempered by war, disciplined by a hard and bitter peace, proud of our ancient heritage, and unwilling to witness or permit the slow undoing of those human rights to which this nation has always been committed, and to which we are committed today at home and around the world sep let every nation know, whether it wishes us well or ill, that we shall pay any price, bear any burden, meet any hardship, support any friend, oppose any foe, to assure the survival and the success of liberty sep this much we pledge -- and more sep to those old allies whose cultural and spiritual origins we share, we pledge the loyalty of faithful friends sep united there is little we cannot do in a host of cooperative ventures sep divided there is little we can do -- for we dare not meet a powerful challenge at odds and split asunder sep to those new states whom we welcome to the ranks of the free, we pledge our word that one form of colonial control shall not have passed away merely to be replaced by a far more iron tyranny sep we shall not always expect to find them supporting our view sep but we shall always hope to find them strongly supporting their own freedom -- and to remember that, in the past, those who foolishly sought power by riding the back of the tiger ended up inside sep to those people in the huts and villages of half the globe struggling to break the bonds of mass misery, we pledge our best efforts to help them help themselves, for whatever period is required -- not because the communists may be doing it, not because we seek their votes, but because it is right sep if a free society cannot help the many who are poor, it cannot save the few who are rich sep to our sister republics south of our border, we offer a special pledge: to convert our good words into good deeds, in a new alliance for progress, to assist free men and free governments in casting off the chains of poverty sep but this peaceful revolution of hope cannot become the prey of hostile powers sep let all our neighbors know that we shall join with them to oppose aggression or subversion anywhere in the americas sep and let every other power know that this hemisphere intends to remain the master of its own house sep to that world assembly of sovereign states, the united nations, our last best hope in an age where the instruments of war have far outpaced the instruments of peace, we renew our pledge of support -- to prevent it from becoming merely a forum for invective, to strengthen its shield of the new and the weak, and to enlarge the area in which its writ may run sep finally, to those nations who would make themselves our adversary, we offer not a pledge but a request: that both sides begin anew the quest for peace, before the dark powers of destruction unleashed by science engulf all humanity in planned or accidental self-destruction sep we dare not tempt them with weakness sep for only when our arms are sufficient beyond doubt can we be certain beyond doubt that they will never be employed sep but neither can two great and powerful groups of nations take comfort from our present course -- both sides overburdened by the cost of modern weapons, both rightly alarmed by the steady spread of the deadly atom, yet both racing to alter that uncertain balance of terror that stays the hand of mankind's final war sep so let us begin anew -- remembering on both sides that civility is not a sign of weakness, and sincerity is always subject to proof sep let us never negotiate out of fear, but let us never fear to negotiate sep let both sides explore what problems unite us instead of belaboring those problems which divide us sep let both sides, for the first time, formulate serious and precise proposals for the inspection and control of arms, and bring the absolute power to destroy other nations under the absolute control of all nations sep let both sides seek to invoke the wonders of science instead of its terrors sep together let us explore the stars, conquer the deserts, eradicate disease, tap the ocean depths, and encourage the arts and commerce sep let both sides unite to heed, in all corners of the earth, the command of isaiah -- to "undo the heavy burdens, and [to] let the oppressed go free sep "and, if a beachhead of cooperation may push back the jungle of suspicion, let both sides join in creating a new endeavor -- not a new balance of power, but a new world of law -- where the strong are just, and the weak secure, and the peace preserved sep all this will not be finished in the first one hundred days sep nor will it be finished in the first one thousand days; nor in the life of this administration; nor even perhaps in our lifetime on this planet sep but let us begin sep in your hands, my fellow citizens, more than mine, will rest the final success or failure of our course sep since this country was founded, each generation of americans has been summoned to give testimony to its national loyalty sep the graves of young americans who answered the call to service surround the globe sep now the trumpet summons us again -- not as a call to bear arms, though arms we need -- not as a call to battle, though embattled we are -- but a call to bear the burden of a long twilight struggle, year in and year out, "ejoicing in hope; patient in tribulation," a struggle against the common enemies of man: tyranny, poverty, disease, and war itself sep can we forge against these enemies a grand and global alliance, north and south, east and west, that can assure a more fruitful life for all mankind sep will you join in that historic effort sep in the long history of the world, only a few generations have been granted the role of defending freedom in its hour of maximum danger sep i do not shrink from this responsibility -- i welcome it sep i do not believe that any of us would exchange places with any other people or any other generation sep the energy, the faith, the devotion which we bring to this endeavor will light our country and all who serve it sep and the glow from that fire can truly light the world sep and so, my fellow americans, ask not what your country can do for you; ask what you can do for your country sep my fellow citizens of the world, ask not what america will do for you, but what together we can do for the freedom of man sep finally, whether you are citizens of america or citizens of the world, ask of us here the same high standards of strength and sacrifice which we ask of you sep with a good conscience our only sure reward, with history the final judge of our deeds, let us go forth to lead the land we love, asking his blessing and his help, but knowing that here on earth god's work must truly be our own sep

president hoover, mr sep chief justice, my friends: this is a day of national consecration sep and i am certain that on this day my fellow americans expect that on my induction into the presidency, i will address them with a candor and a decision which the present situation of our people impels sep this is preeminently the time to speak the truth, the whole truth, frankly and boldly sep nor need we shrink from honestly facing conditions in our country today sep this great nation will endure, as it has endured, will revive and will prosper sep so, first of all, let me assert my firm belief that the only thing we have to fear is fear itself -- nameless, unreasoning, unjustified terror which paralyzes needed efforts to convert retreat into advance sep in every dark hour of our national life, a leadership of frankness and of vigor has met with that understanding and support of the people themselves which is essential to victory sep and i am convinced that you will again give that support to leadership in these critical days sep in such a spirit on my part and on yours we face our common difficulties sep they concern, thank god, only material things sep values have shrunk to fantastic levels; taxes have risen; our ability to pay has fallen; government of all kinds is faced by serious curtailment of income; the means of exchange are frozen in the currents of trade; the withered leaves of industrial enterprise lie on every side; farmers find no markets for their produce; and the savings of many years in thousands of families are gone sep more important, a host of unemployed citizens face the grim problem of existence, and an equally great number toil with little return sep only a foolish optimist can deny the dark realities of the moment sep and yet our distress comes from no failure of substance sep we are stricken by no plague of locusts sep compared with the perils which our forefathers conquered, because they believed and were not afraid, we have still much to be thankful for sep nature still offers her bounty and human efforts have multiplied it sep plenty is at our doorstep, but a generous use of it languishes in the very sight of the supply sep primarily, this is because the rulers of the exchange of mankind's goods have failed, through their own stubbornness and their own incompetence, have admitted their failure, and have abdicated sep practices of the unscrupulous money changers stand indicted in the court of public opinion, rejected by the hearts and minds of men sep true, they have tried sep but their efforts have been cast in the pattern of an outworn tradition sep faced by failure of credit, they have proposed only the lending of more money sep stripped of the lure of profit by which to induce our people to follow their false leadership, they have resorted to exhortations, pleading tearfully for restored confidence sep they only know the rules of a generation of self-seekers sep they have no vision, and when there is no vision the people perish sep yes, the money changers have fled from their high seats in the temple of our civilization sep we may now restore that temple to the ancient truths sep the measure of that restoration lies in the extent to which we apply social values more noble than mere monetary profit sep happiness lies not in the mere possession of money; it lies in the joy of achievement, in the thrill of creative effort sep the joy, the moral stimulation of work no longer must be forgotten in the mad chase of evanescent profits sep these dark days, my friends, will be worth all they cost us if they teach us that our true destiny is not to be ministered unto but to minister to ourselves, to our fellow men sep recognition of that falsity of material wealth as the standard of success goes hand in hand with the abandonment of the false belief that public office and high political position are to be valued only by the standards of pride of place and personal profit; and there must be an end to a conduct in banking and in business which too often has given to a sacred trust the likeness of callous and selfish wrongdoing sep small wonder that confidence languishes, for it thrives only on honesty, on honor, on the sacredness of obligations, on faithful protection, and on unselfish performance; without them it cannot live sep restoration calls, however, not for changes in ethics alone sep this nation is asking for action, and action now sep our greatest primary task is to put people to work sep this is no unsolvable problem if we face it wisely and courageously sep it can be accomplished in part by direct recruiting by the government itself, treating the task as we would treat the emergency of a war, but at the same time, through this employment, accomplishing great -- greatly needed projects to stimulate and reorganize the use of our great natural resources sep hand in hand with that we must frankly recognize the overbalance of population in our industrial centers and, by engaging on a national scale in a redistribution, endeavor to provide a better use of the land for those best fitted for the land sep yes, the task can be helped by definite efforts to raise the values of agricultural products, and with this the power to purchase the output of our cities sep it can be helped by preventing realistically the tragedy of the growing loss through foreclosure of our small homes and our farms sep it can be helped by insistence that the federal, the state, and the local governments act forthwith on the demand that their cost be drastically reduced sep it can be helped by the unifying of relief activities which today are often scattered, uneconomical, unequal sep it can be helped by national planning for and supervision of all forms of transportation and of communications and other utilities that have a definitely public character sep there are many ways in which it can be helped, but it can never be helped by merely talking about it sep we must act sep we must act quickly sep and finally, in our progress towards a resumption of work, we require two safeguards against a return of the evils of the old order sep there must be a strict supervision of all banking and credits and investments sep there must be an end to speculation with other people's money sep and there must be provision for an adequate but sound currency sep these, my friends, are the lines of attack sep i shall presently urge upon a new congress in special session detailed measures for their fulfillment, and i shall seek the immediate assistance of the 48 states sep through this program of action we address ourselves to putting our own national house in order and making income balance outgo sep our international trade relations, though vastly important, are in point of time, and necessity, secondary to the establishment of a sound national economy sep i favor, as a practical policy, the putting of first things first sep i shall spare no effort to restore world trade by international economic readjustment; but the emergency at home cannot wait on that accomplishment sep the basic thought that guides these specific means of national recovery is not nationally -- narrowly nationalistic sep it is the insistence, as a first consideration, upon the interdependence of the various elements in and parts of the united states of america -- a recognition of the old and permanently important manifestation of the american spirit of the pioneer sep it is the way to recovery sep it is the immediate way sep it is the strongest assurance that recovery will endure sep in the field of world policy, i would dedicate this nation to the policy of the good neighbor: the neighbor who resolutely respects himself and, because he does so, respects the rights of others; the neighbor who respects his obligations and respects the sanctity of his agreements in and with a world of neighbors sep if i read the temper of our people correctly, we now realize, as we have never realized before, our interdependence on each other; that we can not merely take, but we must give as well; that if we are to go forward, we must move as a trained and loyal army willing to sacrifice for the good of a common discipline, because without such discipline no progress can be made, no leadership becomes effective sep we are, i know, ready and willing to submit our lives and our property to such discipline, because it makes possible a leadership which aims at the larger good sep this, i propose to offer, pledging that the larger purposes will bind upon us, bind upon us all as a sacred obligation with a unity of duty hitherto evoked only in times of armed strife sep with this pledge taken, i assume unhesitatingly the leadership of this great army of our people dedicated to a disciplined attack upon our common problems sep action in this image, action to this end is feasible under the form of government which we have inherited from our ancestors sep our constitution is so simple, so practical that it is possible always to meet extraordinary needs by changes in emphasis and arrangement without loss of essential form sep that is why our constitutional system has proved itself the most superbly enduring political mechanism the modern world has ever seen sep it has met every stress of vast expansion of territory, of foreign wars, of bitter internal strife, of world relations sep and it is to be hoped that the normal balance of executive and legislative authority may be wholly equal, wholly adequate to meet the unprecedented task before us sep but it may be that an unprecedented demand and need for undelayed action may call for temporary departure from that normal balance of public procedure sep i am prepared under my constitutional duty to recommend the measures that a stricken nation in the midst of a stricken world may require sep these measures, or such other measures as the congress may build out of its experience and wisdom, i shall seek, within my constitutional authority, to bring to speedy adoption sep but, in the event that the congress shall fail to take one of these two courses, in the event that the national emergency is still critical, i shall not evade the clear course of duty that will then confront me sep i shall ask the congress for the one remaining instrument to meet the crisis -- broad executive power to wage a war against the emergency, as great as the power that would be given to me if we were in fact invaded by a foreign foe sep for the trust reposed in me, i will return the courage and the devotion that befit the time sep i can do no less sep we face the arduous days that lie before us in the warm courage of national unity; with the clear consciousness of seeking old and precious moral values; with the clean satisfaction that comes from the stern performance of duty by old and young alike sep we aim at the assurance of a rounded, a permanent national life sep we do not distrust the -- the future of essential democracy sep the people of the united states have not failed sep in their need they have registered a mandate that they want direct, vigorous action sep they have asked for discipline and direction under leadership sep they have made me the present instrument of their wishes sep in the spirit of the gift i take it sep in this dedication -- in this dedication of a nation, we humbly ask the blessing of god sep may he protect each and every one of us sep may he guide me in the days to come

mr sep vice president, mr sep speaker, members of the senate, and of the house of representatives: yesterday, december 7th, 1941 -- a date which will live in infamy -- the united states of america was suddenly and deliberately attacked by naval and air forces of the empire of japan sep the united states was at peace with that nation and, at the solicitation of japan, was still in conversation with its government and its emperor looking toward the maintenance of peace in the pacific sep indeed, one hour after japanese air squadrons had commenced bombing in the american island of oahu, the japanese ambassador to the united states and his colleague delivered to our secretary of state a formal reply to a recent american message sep and while this reply stated that it seemed useless to continue the existing diplomatic negotiations, it contained no threat or hint of war or of armed attack sep 1it will be recorded that the distance of hawaii from japan makes it obvious that the attack was deliberately planned many days or even weeks ago sep during the intervening time, the japanese government has deliberately sought to deceive the united states by false statements and expressions of hope for continued peace sep the attack yesterday on the hawaiian islands has caused severe damage to american naval and military forces sep i regret to tell you that very many american lives have been lost sep in addition, american ships have been reported torpedoed on the high seas between san francisco and honolulu sep yesterday, the japanese government also launched an attack against malaya sep last night, japanese forces attacked hong kong sep last night, japanese forces attacked guam sep last night, japanese forces attacked the philippine islands sep last night, the japanese attacked wake island sep and this morning, the japanese attacked midway island sep japan has, therefore, undertaken a surprise offensive extending throughout the pacific area sep the facts of yesterday and today speak for themselves sep the people of the united states have already formed their opinions and well understand the implications to the very life and safety of our nation sep as commander in chief of the army and navy, i have directed that all measures be taken for our defense sep but always will our whole nation remember the character of the onslaught against us sep no matter how long it may take us to overcome this premeditated invasion, the american people in their righteous might will win through to absolute victory sep i believe that i interpret the will of the congress and of the people when i assert that we will not only defend ourselves to the uttermost, but will make it very certain that this form of treachery shall never again endanger us sep hostilities exist sep there is no blinking at the fact that our people, our territory, and our interests are in grave danger sep with confidence in our armed forces, with the unbounding determination of our people, we will gain the inevitable triumph -- so help us god sep i ask that the congress declare that since the unprovoked and dastardly attack by japan on sunday, december 7th, 1941, a state of war has existed between the united states and the japanese empire

my fellow americans,i come before you tonight as a candidate for the vice presidency and as a man whose honesty and -- and integrity has been questioned sep now, the usual political thing to do when charges are made against you is to either ignore them or to deny them without giving details sep i believe we've had enough of that in the united states, particularly with the present administration in washington, d sep c sep to me the office of the vice presidency of the united states is a great office, and i feel that the people have got to have confidence in the integrity of the men who run for that office and who might obtain it sep i have a theory, too, that the best and only answer to a smear or to an honest misunderstanding of the facts is to tell the truth sep and that's why i'm here tonight sep i want to tell you my side of the case sep i'm sure that you have read the charge, and you've heard it, that i, senator nixon, took 18,000 dollars from a group of my supporters sep now, was that wrong sep and let me say that it was wrong sep i'm saying, incidentally, that it was wrong, not just illegal, because it isn't a question of whether it was legal or illegal, that isn't enough sep the question is, was it morally wrong sep i say that it was morally wrong -- if any of that 18,000 dollars went to senator nixon, for my personal use sep i say that it was morally wrong if it was secretly given and secretly handled sep and i say that it was morally wrong if any of the contributors got special favors for the contributions that they made sep and now to answer those questions let me say this: not one cent of the 18,000 dollars or any other money of that type ever went to me for my personal use sep every penny of it was used to pay for political expenses that i did not think should be charged to the taxpayers of the united states sep it was not a secret fund sep as a matter of fact, when i was on "meet the press" -- some of you may have seen it last sunday -- peter edson came up to me after the program, and he said, "dick, what about this "fund" we hear about sep " and i said, "well, there's no secret about it sep go out and see dana smith who was the administrator of the fund sep " and i gave him [edson] his [smith's] address sep and i said you will find that the purpose of the fund simply was to defray political expenses that i did not feel should be charged to the government sep and third, let me point out -- and i want to make this particularly clear -- that no contributor to this fund, no contributor to any of my campaigns, has ever received any consideration that he would not have received as an ordinary constituent sep i just don't believe in that, and i can say that never, while i have been in the senate of the united states, as far as the people that contributed to this fund are concerned, have i made a telephone call for them to an agency, or have i gone down to an agency in their behalf sep and the records will show that, the records which are in the hands of the administration sep well, then, some of you will say, and rightly, "well, what did you use the fund for, senator sep " "why did you have to have it sep " let me tell you in just a word how a senate office operates sep first of all, a senator gets 15,000 dollars a year in salary sep he gets enough money to pay for one trip a year -- a round trip, that is -- for himself and his family between his home and washington, d sep c sep and then he gets an allowance to handle the people that work in his office to handle his mail sep and the allowance for my state of california is enough to hire 13 people sep and let me say, incidentally, that that allowance is not paid to the senator sep it's paid directly to the individuals that the senator puts on his pay roll sep but all of these people and all of these allowances are for strictly official business; business, for example, when a constituent writes in and wants you to go down to the veteran's administration and get some information about his gi policy -- items of that type, for example sep but there are other expenses which are not covered by the government sep and i think i can best discuss those expenses by asking you some questions sep do you think that when i or any other senator makes a political speech, has it printed, should charge the printing of that speech and the mailing of that speech to the taxpayers sep do you think, for example, when i or any other senator makes a trip to his home state to make a purely political speech that the cost of that trip should be charged to the taxpayers sep do you think when a senator makes political broadcasts or political television broadcasts, radio or television, that the expense of those broadcasts should be charged to the taxpayers sep well i know what your answer is sep it's the same answer that audiences give me whenever i discuss this particular problem: the answer is no sep the taxpayers shouldn't be required to finance items which are not official business but which are primarily political business sep well, then the question arises, you say, "well, how do you pay for these and how can you do it legally sep " and there are several ways that it can be done, incidentally, and that it is done legally in the united states senate and in the congress sep the first way is to be a rich man sep i don't happen perhaps we've forgotten the courage it took for the crew of the shuttle sep but they, the challenger seven, were aware of the dangers, but overcame them and did their jobs brilliantly sep we mourn reverend meza, reverend reck, i'm grateful for your generous invitation to state my views sep while the so-called religious issue is necessarily and properly the chief topic here tonight, i want to emphasize from the outset that i believe that we have far more critical issues in the 1960 campaign; the spread of communist influence, until it now festers only 90 miles from the coast of florida -- the humiliating treatment of our president and vice president by those who no longer respect our power -- the hungry children i saw in west virginia, the old people who cannot pay their doctors bills, the families forced to give up their farms -- an america with too many slums, with too few schools, and too late to the moon and outer space sep these are the real issues which should decide this campaign sep and they are not religious issues -- for war and hunger and ignorance and despair know no religious barrier sep but because i am a catholic, and no catholic has ever been elected president, the real issues in this campaign have been obscured -- perhaps deliberately, in some quarters less responsible than this sep so it is apparently necessary for me to state once again -- not what kind of church i believe in, for that should be important only to me -- but what kind of america i believe in sep i believe in an america where the separation of church and state is absolute; where no catholic prelate would tell the president -- should he be catholic -- how to act, and no protestant minister would tell his parishioners for whom to vote; where no church or church school is granted any public funds or political preference, and where no man is denied public office merely because his religion differs from the president who might appoint him, or the people who might elect him sep i believe in an america that is officially neither catholic, protestant nor jewish; where no public official either requests or accept instructions on public policy from the pope, the national council of churches or any other ecclesiastical source; where no religious body seeks to impose its will directly or indirectly upon the general populace or the public acts of its officials, and where religious liberty is so indivisible that an act against one church is treated as an act against all sep for while this year it may be a catholic against whom the finger of suspicion is pointed, in other years it has been -- and may someday be again -- a jew, or a quaker, or a unitarian, or a baptist sep it was virginia's harassment of baptist preachers, for example, that led to jefferson's statute of religious freedom sep today, i may be the victim, but tomorrow it may be you -- until the whole fabric of our harmonious society is ripped apart at a time of great national peril sep finally, i believe in an america where religious intolerance will someday end, where all men and all churches are treated as equals, where every man has the same right to attend or not to attend the church of his choice, where there is no catholic vote, no anti-catholic vote, no bloc voting of any kind, and where catholics, protestants, and jews, at both the lay and the pastoral levels, will refrain from those attitudes of disdain and division which have so often marred their works in the past, and promote instead the american ideal of brotherhood sep that is the kind of america in which i believe sep and it represents the kind of presidency in which i believe, a great office that must be neither humbled by making it the instrument of any religious group nor tarnished by arbitrarily withholding it -- its occupancy from the members of any one religious group sep i believe in a president whose views on religion are his own private affair, neither imposed upon him by the nation, nor imposed by the nation upon him as a condition to holding that office sep i would not look with favor upon a president working to subvert the first amendment's guarantees of religious liberty; nor would our system of checks and balances permit him to do so sep and neither do i look with favor upon those who would work to subvert article vi of the constitution by requiring a religious test, even by indirection sep for if they disagree with that safeguard, they should be openly working to repeal it sep i want a chief executive whose public acts are responsible to all and obligated to none, who can attend any ceremony, service, or dinner his office may appropriately require of him to fulfill; and whose fulfillment of his presidential office is not limited or conditioned by any religious oath, ritual, or "ligation sep this is the kind of america i believe in -- and this is the kind of america i fought for in the south pacific, and the kind my brother died for in europe sep no one suggested then that we might have a divided loyalty, that we did not believe in liberty, or that we belonged to a disloyal group that threatened -- i quote -- "the freedoms for which our forefathers died sep "and in fact this is the kind of america for which our forefathers did die when they fled here to escape religious test oaths that denied office to members of less favored churches -- when they fought for the constitution, the bill of rights, the virginia statute of religious freedom -- and when they fought at the shrine i visited today, the alamo sep for side by side with bowie and crockett died fuentes, and mccafferty, and bailey, and badillo, and carey -- but no one knows whether they were catholics or not sep for there was no religious test there sep i ask you tonight to follow in that tradition -- to judge me on the basis of 14 years in the congress, on my declared stands against an ambassador to the vatican, against unconstitutional aid to parochial schools, and against any boycott of the public schools -- which i attended myself sep and instead of doing this, do not judge me on the basis of these pamphlets and publications we all have seen that carefully select quotations out of context from the statements of catholic church leaders, usually in other countries, frequently in other centuries, and rarely relevant to any situation here sep and always omitting, of course, the statement of the american bishops in 1948 which strongly endorsed church-state separation, and which more nearly reflects the views of almost every american catholic sep i do not consider these other quotations binding upon my public acts sep why should you sep but let me say, with respect to other countries, that i am wholly opposed to the state being used by any mr sep president, mr sep speaker, and distinguished members of the congress: i stand on this rostrum with a sense of deep humility and great pride -- humility in the wake of those great american architects of our history who have stood here before me; pride in the reflection that this forum of legislative debate represents human liberty in the purest form yet devised sep here are centered the hopes and aspirations and faith of the entire human race sep i do not stand here as advocate for any partisan cause, for the issues are fundamental and reach quite beyond the realm of partisan consideration sep they must be resolved on the highest plane of national interest if our course is to prove sound and our future protected sep i trust, therefore, that you will do me the justice of receiving that which i have to say as solely expressing the considered viewpoint of a fellow american sep i address you with neither rancor nor bitterness in the fading twilight of life, with but one purpose in mind: to serve my country sep the issues are global and so interlocked that to consider the problems of one sector, oblivious to those of another, is but to court disaster for the whole sep while asia is commonly referred to as the gateway to europe, it is no less true that europe is the gateway to asia, and the broad influence of the one cannot fail to have its impact upon the other sep there are those who claim our strength is inadequate to protect on both fronts, that we cannot divide our effort sep i can think of no greater expression of defeatism sep if a potential enemy can divide his strength on two fronts, it is for us to counter his effort sep the communist threat is a global one sep its successful advance in one sector threatens the destruction of every other sector sep you can not appease or otherwise surrender to communism in asia without simultaneously undermining our efforts to halt its advance in europe sep beyond pointing out these general truisms, i shall confine my discussion to the general areas of asia sep before one may objectively assess the situation now existing there, he must comprehend something of asia's past and the revolutionary changes which are -- which have marked her course up to the present sep long exploited by the so-called colonial powers, with little opportunity to achieve any degree of social justice, individual dignity, or a higher standard of life such as guided our own noble administration in the philippines, the peoples of asia found their opportunity in the war just past to throw off the shackles of colonialism and now see the dawn of new opportunity, a heretofore unfelt dignity, and the self-respect of political freedom sep mustering half of the earth's population, and 60 percent of its natural resources these peoples are rapidly consolidating a new force, both moral and material, with which to raise the living standard and erect adaptations of the design of modern progress to their own distinct cultural environments sep whether one adheres to the concept of colonization or not, this is the direction of asian progress and it may not be stopped sep it is a corollary to the shift of the world economic frontiers as the whole epicenter of world affairs rotates back toward the area whence it started sep in this situation, it becomes vital that our own country orient its policies in consonance with this basic evolutionary condition rather than pursue a course blind to the reality that the colonial era is now past and the asian peoples covet the right to shape their own free destiny sep what they seek now is friendly guidance, understanding, and support -- not imperious direction -- the dignity of equality and not the shame of subjugation sep their pre-war standard of life, pitifully low, is infinitely lower now in the devastation left in war's wake sep world ideologies play little part in asian thinking and are little understood sep what the peoples strive for is the opportunity for a little more food in their stomachs, a little better clothing on their backs, a little firmer roof over their heads, and the realization of the normal nationalist urge for political freedom sep these political-social conditions have but an indirect bearing upon our own national security, but do form a backdrop to contemporary planning which must be thoughtfully considered if we are to avoid the pitfalls of unrealism sep of more direct and immediate bearing upon our national security are the changes wrought in the strategic potential of the pacific ocean in the course of the past war sep prior thereto the western strategic frontier of the united states lay on the littoral line of the americas, with an exposed island salient extending out through hawaii, midway, and guam to the philippines sep that salient proved not an outpost of strength but an avenue of weakness along which the enemy could and did attack sep the pacific was a potential area of advance for any predatory force intent upon striking at the bordering land areas sep all this was changed by our pacific victory sep our strategic frontier then shifted to embrace the entire pacific ocean, which became a vast moat to protect us as long as we held it sep indeed, it acts as a protective shield for all of the americas and all free lands of the pacific ocean area sep we control it to the shores of asia by a chain of islands extending in an arc from the aleutians to the mariannas held by us and our free allies sep from this island chain we can dominate with sea and air power every asiatic port from vladivostok to singapore -- with sea and air power every port, as i said, from vladivostok to singapore -- and prevent any hostile movement into the pacific sep *any predatory attack from asia must be an amphibious effort sep * no amphibious force can be successful without control of the sea lanes and the air over those lanes in its avenue of advance sep with naval and air supremacy and modest ground elements to defend bases, any major attack from continental asia toward us or our friends in the pacific would be doomed to failure sep under such conditions, the pacific no longer represents menacing avenues of approach for a prospective invader sep it assumes, instead, the friendly aspect of a peaceful lake sep our line of defense is a natural one and can be maintained with a minimum of military effort and expense sep it envisions no attack against anyone, nor does it provide the bastions essential for offensive operations, but properly maintained, would be an invincible defense against aggression sep the holding of this littoral defense line in the western pacific is entirely dependent upon holding all segments thereof; for any major breach of that line by an unfriendly power would render vulnerable to determined attack every other major segment sep this is a military estimate as to which i have yet to find a military leader who will take exception sep for that reason, i have strongly recommended in the past, as a matter of military urgency, that under no circumstances must formosa fall under communist control sep such an eventuality would at once threaten the freedom of the philippines and the loss of japan and might well force our western frontier back to the coast of california, oregon and washington sep to understand the changes which now appear upon the chinese mainland, one must understand the changes in chinese character and culture over the past 50 years sep china, up to 50 years ago, was completely non-homogenous, being compartmented into groups divided against each other sep the war-making tendency was almost non-existent, as they still followed the tenets of the confucian ideal of pacifist culture sep at the turn of the century, under the regime of chang tso lin, efforts toward greater homogeneity produced the start of a nationalist urge sep this was further and more successfully developed under the leadership of chiang kai-shek, but has been brought to its greatest fruition under the present regime to the point that it has now taken on the character of a united nationalism of increasingly dominant, aggressive tendencies sep through these past 50 years the chinese people have thus become militarized in their concepts and in their ideals sep they now constitute excellent soldiers, with competent staffs and commanders sep this has produced a new and dominant power in asia, which, for its own purposes, is allied with soviet russia but which in its own concepts and methods has become aggressively imperialistic, with a lust for expansion and increased power normal to this type of imperialism sep there is little of the ideological concept either one way or another in the chinese make-up sep the standard of living is so low and the capital accumulation has been so thoroughly dissipated by war that the masses are desperate and eager to follow any leadership which seems to promise the alleviation of local stringencies sep i have from the beginning believed that the chinese communists' support of the north koreans was the dominant one sep their interests are, at present, parallel with those of the soviet sep but i believe that the aggressiveness recently displayed not only in korea but also in indo-china and tibet and pointing potentially toward the south reflects predominantly the same lust for the expansion of power which has animated every would-be conqueror since the beginning of time sep the japanese people, since the war, have undergone the greatest reformation recorded in modern history sep with a commendable will, eagerness to learn, and marked capacity to understand, they have, from the ashes left in war's wake, erected in japan an edifice dedicated to the supremacy of individual liberty and personal dignity; and in the ensuing process there has been created a truly representative government committed to the advance of political morality, freedom of economic enterprise, and social justice sep politically, economically, and socially japan is now abreast of many free nations of the earth and will not again fail the universal trust sep that it may be counted upon to wield a profoundly beneficial influence over the course of events in asia is attested by the magnificent manner in which the japanese people have met the recent challenge of war, unrest, and confusion surrounding them from the outside and checked communism within their own frontiers without the slightest slackening in their forward progress sep i sent all four of our occupation divisions to the korean battlefront without the slightest qualms as to the effect of the resulting power vacuum upon japan sep the results fully justified my faith sep i know of no nation more serene, orderly, and industrious, nor in which higher hopes can be entertained for future constructive service in the advance of the human race sep of our former ward, the philippines, we can look forward in confidence that the existing unrest will be corrected and a strong and healthy nation will grow in the longer aftermath of war's terrible destructiveness sep we must be patient and understanding and never fail them -- as in our hour of need, they did not fail us sep a christian nation, the philippines stand as a mighty bulwark of christianity in the far east, and its capacity for high moral leadership in asia is unlimited sep on formosa, the government of the republic of china has had the opportunity to refute by action much of the malicious gossip which so undermined the strength of its leadership on the chinese mainland sep the formosan people are receiving a just and enlightened administration with majority representation on the organs of government, and politically, economically, and socially they appear to be advancing along sound and constructive lines sep with this brief insight into the surrounding areas, i now turn to the korean conflict sep while i was not consulted prior to the president's decision to intervene in support of the republic of korea, that decision from a military standpoint, proved a sound one, as we -- as i said, proved a sound one, as we hurled back the invader and decimated his forces sep our victory was complete, and our objectives within reach, when red china intervened with numerically superior ground forces sep this created a new war and an entirely new situation, a situation not contemplated when our forces were committed against the north korean invaders; a situation which called for new decisions in the diplomatic sphere to permit the realistic adjustment of military strategy sep such decisions have not been forthcoming sep while no man in his right mind would advocate sending our ground forces into continental china, and such was never given a thought, the new situation did urgently demand a drastic revision of strategic planning if our political aim was to defeat this new enemy as we had defeated the old sep apart from the military need, as i saw it, to neutralize the sanctuary protection given the enemy north of the yalu, i felt that military necessity in the conduct of the war made necessary: first the intensification of our economic blockade against china; two the imposition of a naval blockade against the china coast; three removal of restrictions on air reconnaissance of china's coastal areas and of manchuria; four removal of restrictions on the forces of the republic of china on formosa, with logistical support to contribute to their effective operations against the common enemy sep for entertaining these views, all professionally designed to support our forces committed to korea and bring hostilities to an end with the least possible delay and at a saving of countless american and allied lives, i have been severely criticized in lay circles, principally abroad, despite my understanding that from a military standpoint the above views have been fully shared in the past by practically every military leader concerned with the korean campaign, including our own joint chiefs of staff sep i called for reinforcements but was informed that reinforcements were not available sep i made clear that if not permitted to destroy the enemy built-up bases north of the yalu, if not permitted to utilize the friendly chinese force of some 600,000 men on formosa, if not permitted to blockade the china coast to prevent the chinese reds from getting succor from without, and if there were to be no hope of major reinforcements, the position of the command from the military standpoint forbade victory sep we could hold in korea by constant maneuver and in an approximate area where our supply line advantages were in balance with the supply line disadvantages of the enemy, but we could hope at best for only an indecisive campaign with its terrible and constant attrition upon our forces if the enemy utilized its full military potential sep i have constantly called for the new political decisions essential to a solution sep efforts have been made to distort my position sep it has been said, in effect, that i was a warmonger sep nothing could be further from the truth sep i know war as few other men now living know it, and nothing to me is more revolting sep i have long advocated its complete abolition, as its very destructiveness on both friend and foe has rendered it useless as a means of settling international disputes sep indeed, on the second day of september, nineteen hundred and forty-five, just following the surrender of the japanese nation on the battleship missouri, i formally cautioned as follows: men since the beginning of time have sought peace sep various methods through the ages have been attempted to devise an international process to prevent or settle disputes between nations sep from the very start workable methods were found in so far as individual citizens were concerned, but the mechanics of an instrumentality of larger international scope have never been successful sep military alliances, balances of power, leagues of nations, all in turn failed, leaving the only path to be by way of the crucible of war sep the utter destructiveness of war now blocks out this alternative sep we have had our last chance sep if we will not devise some greater and more equitable system, armageddon will be at our door sep the problem basically is theological and involves a spiritual recrudescence and improvement of human character that will synchronize with our almost matchless advances in science, art, literature, and all material and cultural developments of the past 2000 years sep it must be of the spirit if we are to save the flesh sep but once war is forced upon us, there is no other alternative than to apply every available means to bring it to a swift end sep war's very object is victory, not prolonged indecision sep in war there is no substitute for victory sep there are some who, for varying reasons, would appease red china sep they are blind to history's clear lesson, for history teaches with unmistakable emphasis that appeasement but begets new and bloodier war sep it points to no single instance where this end has justified that means, where appeasement has led to more than a sham peace sep like blackmail, it lays the basis for new and successively greater demands until, as in blackmail, violence becomes the only other alternative sep "why," my soldiers asked of me, "surrender military advantages to an enemy in the field sep " i could not answer sep some may say: to avoid spread of the conflict into an all-out war with china; others, to avoid soviet intervention sep neither explanation seems valid, for china is already engaging with the maximum power it can commit, and the soviet will not necessarily mesh its actions with our moves sep like a cobra, any new enemy will more likely strike whenever it feels that the relativity in military or other potential is in its favor on a world-wide basis sep the tragedy of korea is further heightened by the fact that its military action is confined to its territorial limits sep it condemns that nation, which it is our purpose to save, to suffer the devastating impact of full naval and air bombardment while the enemy's sanctuaries are fully protected from such attack and devastation sep of the nations of the world, korea alone, up to now, is the sole one which has risked its all against communism sep the magnificence of the courage and fortitude of the korean people defies description sep they have chosen to risk death rather than slavery sep their last words to me were: "don't scuttle the pacific sep "i have just left your fighting sons in korea sep they have met all tests there, and i can report to you without reservation that they are splendid in every way sep it was my constant effort to preserve them and end this savage conflict honorably and with the least loss of time and a minimum sacrifice of life sep its growing bloodshed has caused me the deepest anguish and anxiety sep those gallant men will remain often in my thoughts and in my prayers always sep i am closing my 52 years of military service sep when i joined the army, even before the turn of the century, it was the fulfillment of all of my boyish hopes and dreams sep the world has turned over many times since i took the oath on the plain at west point, and the hopes and dreams have long since vanished, but i still remember the refrain of one of the most popular barrack ballads of that day which proclaimed most proudly that "old soldiers never die; they just fade away sep "and like the old soldier of that ballad, i now close my military career and just fade away, an old soldier who tried to do his duty as god gave him the light to see that duty sep good bye

thank you very kindly, my friends sep as i listened to ralph abernathy and his eloquent and generous introduction and then thought about myself, i wondered who he was talking about sep it's always spite of a storm warning sep you reveal that you are determined to go on anyhow sep something is happening in memphis; something is happening in our world sep and you know, if i were standing at the beginning of time, with the possibility of taking a kind of general and panoramic view of the whole of human history up to now, and the almighty said to me, "martin luther king, which age would you like to live in sep " i would take my mental flight by egypt and i would watch god's children in their magnificent trek from the dark dungeons of egypt through, or rather across the red sea, through the wilderness on toward the promised land sep and in spite of its magnificence, i wouldn't stop there sep i would move on by greece and take my mind to mount olympus sep and i would see plato, aristotle, socrates, euripides and aristophanes assembled around the parthenon sep and i would watch them around the parthenon as they discussed the great and eternal issues of reality sep but i wouldn't stop there sep i would go on, even to the great heyday of the roman empire sep and i would see developments around there, through various emperors and leaders sep but i wouldn't stop there sep i would even come up to the day of the renaissance, and get a quick picture of all that the renaissance did for the cultural and aesthetic life of man sep but i wouldn't stop there sep i would even go by the way that the man for whom i am named had his habitat sep and i would watch martin luther as he tacked his ninety-five theses on the door at the church of wittenberg sep but i wouldn't stop there sep i would come on up even to 1863, and watch a vacillating president by the name of abraham lincoln finally come to the conclusion that he had to sign the emancipation proclamation sep but i wouldn't stop there sep i would even come up to the early thirties, and see a man grappling with the problems of the bankruptcy of his nation sep and come with an eloquent cry that we have nothing to fear but "fear itself sep " but i wouldn't stop there sep strangely enough, i would turn to the almighty, and say, "if you allow me to live just a few years in the second half of the 20th century, i will be happy sep "now that's a strange statement to make, because the world is all messed up sep the nation is sick sep trouble is in the land; confusion all around sep that's a strange statement sep but i know, somehow, that only when it is dark enough can you see the stars sep and i see god working in this period of the twentieth century in a way that men, in some strange way, are responding sep something is happening in our world sep the masses of people are rising up sep and wherever they are assembled today, whether they are in johannesburg, south africa; nairobi, kenya; accra, ghana; new york city; atlanta, georgia; jackson, mississippi; or memphis, tennessee -- the cry is always the same: "we want to be free sep "and another reason that i'm happy to live in this bring the colored peoples of the world out of their long years of poverty, their long years of hurt and neglect, the whole world is doomed sep now, i'm just happy that god has allowed me to live in we've got to keep attention on that sep that's always the problem with a little violence sep you know what happened the other day, and the press dealt only with the window-breaking sep i read the
